respondent.name: UNITED STATES; and JUNE CARABELL, ET AL., Petitioners v. No. 04-1384 UNITED STATES ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Rapanos v. United States and Carabell v. the United States Army Corps of Engineers. Mr. Hopper.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It goes somewhat beyond the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 smallest trickle? Doesn't it? Doesn't it also include ditches that currently don't have any trickle if they obtain a trickle during a rainstorm?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So where would you -- where would -- where would you put the line?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But then -- but you were 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 -- you are including at least wetlands that abut --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- navigable water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about major tributaries?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Which ones?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, is your position no tributaries or some tributaries?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Does it make sense to say that any wetlands that it abuts a traditionally navigable water is covered, but a tributary that leads 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 right into a traditionally navigable water is not necessarily covered?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but they're doing it for a functional reason. The functional reason is that if you put the poison in the adjacent wetland, it's going to get into the navigable water. Exactly the same argument can be made as you go further and further up the tributaries, and it seems to me that once you concede, as I think you have to, that there can be a regulation that goes beyond literally navigable water at the point at which the -- the pollutant is added, then you have to follow the same logic right up through the watershed to -- to any point at which a pollutant, once added, will eventually get into the navigable water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then -- then you have to accept the fact that -- that Congress cannot effectively regulate the navigable -- the -- the condition of the navigable water itself because if all the -- the -- let's -- let's assume there's a class of -- of evil polluters out there who just want to wreck the -- the navigable waters of the United States. All they have to do is get far enough upstream and they can dump anything they want to. It will eventually get into the navigable water, and Congress can't do anything about it on your theory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So you're -- you're going to -- you -- you then want to draw a distinction between the dredge and fill addition and, let's say, a -- a conventional synthetic poison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You mean on -- on -- in every -- in every case then, I mean, Congress would have to -- I'm sorry -- a scientist would have to analyze the molecules and -- and trace them up, and so long as they could -- could trace it to a specific discharge, they could get at it, but otherwise they couldn't? I mean, that -- you know, you know what I'm getting at. That obviously would -- would totally thwart the regulation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Couldn't you simply assume that anything that is discharged into a tributary ultimately goes where the tributary goes? Wouldn't it be enough to prove the discharge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you don't think it would be enough for the -- for the Government to prove the discharge into a tributary in order to prove that the act has been violated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You really think it has to trace the molecules.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How do you -- how do you define a tributary?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So what's your definition?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I know what you object to, and I know that you think your client isn't covered. But I don't know what test you would have us adopt for what constitutes a tributary.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay, but we 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 still don't know what you're excluding. I mean, the Missouri is a tributary of the Mississippi, but I assume it's still covered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it -- it seems to me that what works in your favor is -- is it SWANCC? I don't -- I'm not quite sure how to pronounce the case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The Migratory Bird Rule case where we said there had to be a significant nexus. But I think what the Court is asking you is -- is how to define significant nexus. We're -- if you want us just to say, well, this case is too much, but then the Corps of Engineers should use its expertise to come up with a new regulation, that's rather an odd opinion for us to write.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And it seems to me that that's what you're asking us to do here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: From everything -- from everything you said, it sounds like you're -- you're taking issue with Riverside Bayview because if a wetland adjacent to the river counts, then why not a stream that goes right into it? What sense does that distinction make?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: More than that, Mr. Hopper. I thought and I had expected you to -- to respond to Justice Souter's question this way, his question about how come putting poison in -- in the wetlands is bad, but it's okay to put it in the tributary. But they -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 as I understand it, the reason we held wetlands were included within the waters of the United States was not -- not that, that you could poison the waters by poisoning the wetlands, but rather, it was that it's very hard to tell where the navigable water ends and the wetland begins. And -- and we said, you know, we're not going to parse that. If it's -- if it's adjacent to a navigable water and it's wet, we're going to say it's part of a navigable water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought that was our basis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And, of course, that basis doesn't apply to tributaries, does it? You -- you can always tell where the tributary ends. It ends at the point where it goes into the main river.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You think that's correct about what the Court said in Bayview when it phrased the question as before discharging fill material into wetlands adjacent to navigable bodies of water and their tributaries. That's what the Court thought it was deciding in Riverside Bayview. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: At any rate, they could not have been making the distinction Justice Scalia suggested if, at least in the Court's thinking, the tributaries rolled right into the navigable body.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but doesn't the reference to tributary make it relatively plain that what the Court was getting at was the impossibility of drawing a functional distinction between wetlands and tributaries on the one hand, navigable waters on the other, when the purpose of the regulation is to protect the purity of the ultimate navigable water? And isn't the inclusion of the reference to tributaries an 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 indication that it said if we want to attain the objective, which is clearly constitutional, then we have got to recognize these means, i.e., regulation of -- of pollution in wetlands and tributaries, in order to reach that objective? Isn't that the reasoning that is apparent from what Justice Ginsburg just -- just read to you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, it's -- except for the -- it seems to me except for -- for your -- your argument is -- is fine except for one problem. And that is, if we -- if we assume that Congress was being as -- as cautious as you suggest, then Congress' caution, in effect, was -- was allowing an end run around the regulation for the reasons we went into a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 moment ago. All you've got to do is -- is dump the pollutant further -- far enough upstream in the watershed and you get away scot-free. And it's very difficult to believe that Congress could have intended that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But if -- but your -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 but your answer earlier to Justice Souter's earlier question was that if you dump the pollutants anywhere and they make their way to the navigable water, you're covered. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Stoepker.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Did we talk about a hydrological connection in Riverside Bayview?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm not sure what you mean by a hydrological connection. Do you mean a constant -- a constant body of water between the two, or do you mean simply a -- a drain that at some times might carry off rainwater from -- from this land? And -- would that -- would that suffice to be a hydrological connection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Water never ran off of this -- of this land.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, do they have to make this on a plot-by-plot basis, or can they make a categorical judgment that even in cases in which, you know, there's a berm, as there is here, when the water is high, it spills over? And if the categorical judgment is sound, do you have an exception because they haven't proven it with respect to your particular lot?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Where do you get that exception?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And the -- and the -- but I mean, what I'm getting at is the traditional test is the basis for a categorical judgment. Your land falls within the general category. Your argument is I should not be subject to it, to the statute, because of the general category. I should be subject to it only if they prove specifically that the water spills over in rainy periods in my particular lot. In other words, you're saying there's got to be a specific connection as opposed to a categorical judgment. And my question is what under the act supports that view.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So -- so your -- maybe what you're saying is we have shown or the record shows that this doesn't fit within the category because it never spills over or whatever. Is that your argument? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Am I correct --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Stoepker, your friend, Mr. Hopper, would certainly not agree with you that -- that a -- a hydrological connection is the, quote, traditional test. What -- what is your definition of tradition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How long has this test been established?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Traditionally.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: From the inception of the rules.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That that alone has been enough.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I see. So you're -- you're not conceding that -- that hydrologic -- hydrological connection is adequate. You're just -- is sufficient. You're just saying it's necessary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Can I get back to the question earlier? What is a hydrological connection? Is it enough if the water seeps through the ground and underground is connected with the navigable water, or does there have to be a ditch or -- or a culvert that you can see the water flowing through?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Was it -- was it also clear that after the improvement, there would be no drainage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I just ask one clarifying question? Was it found that there was no connection, or was it not found that there was a connection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It was. I didn't read it that way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Where are you reading from?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Right. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm sorry. I want to be sure I follow you. You say that somewhere on page 82 there is a finding that there was no hydrological connection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: They don't find a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I agree with that. I'm asking you if they found there was no hydrological connection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But not on page 82.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is the report in the -- is the subsequent report in the record somewhere?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And again, where --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What page are you on?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Where are you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Then what was the reason they gave for rejecting the permit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Suppose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- I'm still not clear as to what the findings were, if there were findings, as 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 to what the condition would be after the improvement. Would there be an increased likelihood of drainage into the ditch after the improvement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and if that were so, would that be sufficient for jurisdiction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But, well -- suppose the interaction were automatic. Would that suffice to make this a wetlands after the improvement?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, what -- what is the test that you would have us adopt for a significant nexus?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: By that, you mean either a ditch or underground seepage?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay. So there has -- there has to be any -- and any hydrological connection works.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Hopper won't like that, but for --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't -- you don't have to define what -- everything that's necessary. All you have to define is one indispensable element. And all you're arguing is that a hydrological connection is an indispensable element, whatever additional elements --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- there may be. So you may agree with your friend, Mr. Hopper.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you just haven't reached that point. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But I'm still puzzled --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't want to set you two to fighting with each other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- by your answer to Justice -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- Justice Kennedy. What 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 if there's no hydrological connection today, but there would be after you -- after you built your project?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But it -- would it be a sufficient reason to deny a permit based on the judgment that after the project is completed, there will be a -- a hydrological connection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No. It seems to me you could answer that yes or no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Perhaps you don't want to but -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But isn't it sort of foolish to say that we're concerned about pollution, but only if you -- only if you catch it in advance? That doesn't make sense because if the problem would 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 arise when you did what you're seeking a permit to do, why shouldn't you be denied the permit?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, but my hypothesis is that we know it would happen, or they -- they would find it would happen after the project is completed. And it seems to me that -- that that's what you should focus on rather than what's -- you know, rather than what happens before.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What we're talking about here is -- is at -- at most, whether this is a water of the United States. The condition for requiring permits is that it -- it be a water of the United States. Isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it either is or it isn't, not -- not that it will be. It either is or it isn't. If it is, you -- you need a permit; if it isn't, you don't need a permit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And Justice Stevens' question I think in -- in that framework is -- is this. If it will result in discharge after the project, is it a water of the United States now?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then -- then Congress has passed a statute that says we'll lock the barn after the horse is stolen. I mean, that -- maybe that's what it did, but that's -- that would be a very odd thing for it to do, wouldn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, it -- it would do so in -- in cases of -- I guess, of the -- the sorts of -- of new proposed actions that require the -- the Corps to get into it in the first place. But I also assume that it would leave lots of -- of water pollution regulation to the States. I don't see that it would displace the States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the only reason it's a water of the United States is that there are some puddles on this land. Right? And if there were no puddles, it -- it wouldn't be a water of the United States. It would just be land of the United States. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it -- it becomes waters of the United States because there are puddles on it, and you assert because those puddles have some hydrological connection or if it is -- if it is water of the United States, those puddles have some hydrological connections with the navigable waters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and the -- the statute only prohibits the discharge of dredged or fill material, which is what is going on here, into the navigable waters, right, at specified disposal sites. I'm sorry. The -- the permits that -- that are required here --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- permit discharge into waters, not -- not into lands that aren't waters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I ask one question about your -- your not -- no hydrological connection? If this berm were next to a wetland that would otherwise be adjacent to a river, the situation that was presented in Riverside Bayview, is it the berm that prevents there being a hydrological connection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So it could -- there could be a situation where the wetlands would be right next to the river, but there's a berm in between, and that would break the hydrological connection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think it -- do you think it mean adjacent with a berm in between? I -- I thought the reason they -- they reached that conclusion was you can't tell where the navigable water ends and where the wetland begins. I -- I thought they assumed a connection between the two.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You may respond briefly. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: General Clement.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How do you define tributary?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The tributary -- you say they're adjacent to a nonnavigable tributary. That's a -- a culvert, a ditch. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But in Rapanos' case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What about -- what about the other -- the other sites?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But your argument assumes that the ditches that go to the other two sites are also tributaries.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even when it's not a body of water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A storm drain, even -- even when it's not filled with water, is a tributary. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I suggest it's very absurd to call that waters of the United States. It's a drainage ditch dug -- you know, dug by the municipality or -- you know, or a gutter in a street. To call that waters of the United States seems to me extravagant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what percentage of the -- of the territory of the United States do you believe is -- is subjected to permits from the Corps of Engineers on your theory whenever you want to move dirt, whenever you want to deposit sand? What -- what 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 percentage of the total land mass of the United States, if you define tributary as broadly as you define it to include? Every storm drain? I mean, it's the whole country, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All the water goes down to the sea and there's some kind of a drain or -- or a bed that takes the water down there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're calling empty ditches -- not unless you call empty ditches land, which I do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I understand that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But -- but you -- that's just because this statute happens to refer to wetlands. But under your theory, the Corps of Engineers would have jurisdiction over any land that is part of that tributary system as well. If any of that land has a deposit of -- of some materials that could leach into or -- or drain into the -- the tributary system, which is to say any gutter, in theory, the -- the Federal Government can regulate it all. No?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But in 1899, it just said navigable rivers, not -- not every -- every tributary defined to include even storm drains.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But your -- your theory is there is regulatory authority because there's an interaction between the wetlands or the lands in question and the navigable waters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but -- but wasn't -- wasn't the reason for including the adjacent wetlands because of -- of the likelihood of an interaction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, let -- well, please finish. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well -- well, as you mention that, you cited subsection (7), and there's a -- what struck me anyway as a very interesting provision in there. It covers wetlands adjacent to waters other than waters that are themselves wetlands. Now, everything that you've said today and in your brief would lead me to think you would contend that wetlands that are adjacent to wetlands ought to be covered as well, and yet, the regulation leaves them out. And I want to know why do you think the regulation leaves those wetlands out. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: To me it -- it suggests that even the Corps recognized that at some point you've got to say stop because logically any drop of water anywhere is going to have some sort of connection through drainage. And they're -- they're stopping there, and I wonder if we ought to take that same instinct that -- that you see in subsection (7) and apply it to your definition of tributary and say, at some point, the definition of tributary has to have an end. Otherwise, you're going to go and reach too far, beyond what Congress reasonably intended.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's true of the wetland that is adjacent to the wetland that is adjacent to the tributary, and yet, the Corps says we're not going to reach the wetland that is adjacent to another wetland.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Your assumption --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- but this -- this is preliminary to my question. In SWANCC, we said there has to be a significant nexus. It seems to me that you have to show that there's some significant relation between the wetlands you're regulating or seeking to regulate and the navigable water.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I -- and that's just, it seemed to me, so far been missing from the discussion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What -- what about the Chief Justice's question, wetlands next to wetlands?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, but we didn't come up with the idea of wetlands next to wetlands. The Corps of Engineers has it in their regulations.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So what do they mean by it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What -- what is an example of an insignificant nexus under the SWANCC test?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No. There's no nexus there.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: They're isolated. There's no nexus. The -- the notion in SWANCC of a significant nexus suggests that there are some bodies of water or puddles that are going to have a nexus, but it's not going to be significant enough. We didn't just say any nexus. It said significant nexus. So what are you leaving out to give meaning to the test that we articulated in SWANCC?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So if you have a wetland, you would say a wetland with a hydrological connection to a tributary of navigable waters through one drop a year is a significant nexus to the waters of the United States?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: One drop.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Adjacent to what? Adjacent to a tributary. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But -- but here's -- here's the fly in the ointment. You -- you interpret tributary to include storm drains and ditches that only carry off rainwater. I mean, it makes an immense difference to the scope of jurisdiction of the Corps of Engineers. I mean, when you talk about adjacent to a tributary, I think, you know, maybe adjacent to the Missouri River or something like that. No. You're talking about adjacent to a storm drain.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Only because I don't know how a storm drain is a water of the United States. That's all. I mean, all of these terms that you're 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 throwing around somehow have to come within a reasonable usage of the term, waters of the United States, and I do not see how a storm drain under anybody's concept is a water of the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. I was referring to a real storm drain. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And some aren't. But -- but you would sweep them all into the jurisdiction of the Corps of Engineers.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Am I right that a tributary is not a defined term in the regulations? Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, but that -- but that doesn't follow. I mean, it is not a principle of law that so long as the object is -- is lawful and within the power of the United States, all means to which even that object are lawful. That is simply not true. There are various means of stopping that pollution, and it may well be that one of the means, which intrudes too deeply into the State's power to regulate land 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 within their jurisdiction, is not a permissible one. That -- that's not an extraordinary proposition.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't see how non-point source pollution is -- is any more remote from what the Federal Government should be able to do to achieve its ends than is a point source pollution that -- that consists of -- of dumping sand on land that has some puddles on it. I -- that seems to me just as remote.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that's not really fair. The Petitioners, as I understand it, both concede the discharges that make their way into the navigable waters would be covered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But the Congress in 1972 also, in its statement of policy, said it's a statement of policy to reserve to the States the power and the responsibility to plan land use and water resources. And under your definition, I -- I just see that we're giving no scope at all to that clear statement of a congressional policy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Though not necessarily as far as storm drains. It would be enough to -- to say navigable -- you know, non-navigable tributaries that are real -- real tributaries.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's a very vague indication. I mean, I -- I agree with you that your argument based on 404(g) is a strong one, but it -- it perhaps is weakened if you believe that in order to stretch to the -- to the limit of Federal jurisdiction, you need a clear statement. I certainly wouldn't consider 404(g) -- if -- if the act did not previously include the kind of authority you're arguing for, I would not -- I would not consider 404(g) a clear statement of that -- of that new -- new authority.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Could you just say a word about the -- the ditch -- sorry -- the word about the wetland next to a tributary that's separated by a man- made object like a ditch? Are there many such instances? It sounds to me like a scientific question. Are there many such instances where there is no transfer of water? And in those instances, is the presence of water in the wetland anything more than a coincidence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Insofar as it seeks to serve a purpose of the statute to regulate this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And where do I look to verify that scientific matter?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No. I can't find any quantitative assessment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. Now suppose we take a set, which you think exists as not the null set, of instances where there is no such transfer, which your opponents say is this case. Now what's the justification for regulating those? If it's simply flood control because water flows over the top and sits there, I guess you could say the same thing is true of any low depression, and therefore, the presence of water would be just a coincidence. Now, what's your -- the fact that they're wet doesn't have anything to do with it. It's the fact that they're next to a place that floods that has to do 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 with it. Now, what's wrong with what I just said?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay, I understand that. Now, what specifically, since I think this is scientific, do I look at to verify what you just said, namely that a wet depression, even if there's no interchange, has a lot to do with flood control that a dry depression wouldn't have? That's a scientific statement. Where do I verify it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I read them, and I -- I just perhaps wasn't reading them closely enough, but I just can't find the verification directly there. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, what am I supposed to do with the case? I read them quickly. I don't necessarily pick up everything. I'll read them again. But if I don't find empirical verification for that statement, what am I supposed to do with this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. And where did the agency, in its many, many proceedings over the course of 35 years, say what you just said, namely that a wetland acts as a sponge? It's very plausible to me. It's just that there may be a need to drop a citation somewhere. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And if you wanted a cite for the opposite proposition, you could cite subsection (7) of the Corps' regulations where they have no interest in wetlands that happen to be adjacent to other wetlands that are adjacent to the waters of the United States. If they act in the way that you've been postulating, presumably they'd want to cover those adjacent wetlands just as much as they want to cover the wetlands that are next to the tributary, but they don't.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It doesn't -- it doesn't say that. It says other than waters that are themselves wetlands. It excludes all wetlands that are adjacent to wetlands that are adjacent to waters of the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So you say that the authority of -- I don't -- I don't even think the Corps has ever suggested this. The authority of the Corps extends not only to all that you've -- we've been talking about and that you've asserted, but also to lands that, if altered, could have some hydrological connection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What is -- what is the basis for their doing it? If there is currently no hydrological connection, there is a berm, there is no -- there is no connection to the navigable waters of the United -- what could possibly be the basis for their asserting jurisdiction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A statute could do that. A 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 statute could do that. But this statute requires that it be a water of the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and when -- when there is nothing but puddles that are isolated by a berm, even from the storm drain which goes to tributaries, I can't conceive of -- of how you could consider that that's -- you know, at least where it leaks sometimes into the storm drain and went down to a tributary, I think it's an exaggeration, but maybe you could call it a water of the United States. But where there's a berm that prevents any water from going even into the storm drain which then goes into a tributary, how can you possibly consider that a water of the United States?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's not the argument I was addressing. I'm addressing the argument that in changing the land, you may cause it to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm happy to hear that. That's all I was trying to establish. You -- you don't assert that that's an independent basis.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You -- you put a lot of weight on the tributary question in your approach by giving up the hydrological connection. Your response is you don't need a hydrological connection because it's right next to a tributary. But for those of us who are having a little trouble with the concept of tributary, you don't leave us much to fall back on.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, General. Mr. Hopper, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Hopper, I hope you're going to tell us what you make of section 404(g).

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: We're told that one of them was much closer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the Pine River? Are you -- that's not 20 miles away, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you know? The -- the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Solicitor General represented to us that it was very close. Are you disputing that as a matter of fact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Of course, when we're talking about the scope of -- of Federal power, we're not merely concerned with dumping refuse in the creek, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 but also deliberate attempts to poison the water system.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No. The fact that the States have the power and the interest does not necessarily mean that the Federal Government does not also have the power.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You may respond briefly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
